questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents with lower abdominal pain and vaginal spotting at 7 weeks of gestation. An ultrasound confirms an ectopic pregnancy. Which of the following statements about progesterone in ectopic pregnancy is most accurate?

choices.text: Progesterone levels are typically higher in ectopic pregnancies compared to normal intrauterine pregnancies.
Low serum progesterone levels can help differentiate between ectopic and intrauterine pregnancies.
Progesterone is used as a first-line treatment for ectopic pregnancies.
High progesterone levels are a definitive indicator of a viable intrauterine pregnancy

questions.solution:
Correct option: B) Low serum progesterone levels can help differentiate between ectopic and intrauterine pregnancies.
Explanation:
Low serum progesterone levels can help differentiate between ectopic and intrauterine pregnancies, as lower levels are often associated with non-viable pregnancies, including ectopic pregnancies.

Serum progesterone levels:

  • >25 ng/ml indicates viable intrauterine pregnancy
  • < 5 ng/ml indicates non-viable intrauterine pregnancy or ectopic pregnancy

Higher progesterone levels are generally indicative of a normal, viable intrauterine pregnancy. (Option A)
Progesterone is not used as a treatment for ectopic pregnancies. (Option C)
High progesterone levels are not used as a definitive marker. (Option D)

questions.text: Which is the most common non-tubal site for an ectopic pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct option: A) Ovary


Explanation:

  • The most common site for ectopic pregnancy: Ampulla
  • The most common non-tubal site is the ovary
  • In the tubes: Ampulla > Isthmus > Infundibulum > Interstitial (least common)
  • Abdominal ectopic pregnancy is one of the least common sites of ectopic pregnancy (Option C)

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with acute lower abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. She has a positive pregnancy test. Her medical history includes a previous chlamydial infection and smoking. She also developed GDM and was preeclamptic in her last pregnancy. Which of the following is the most likely risk factor contributing to her ectopic pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct option: B) History of chlamydial infection


Explanation:
A history of chlamydial infection is a significant risk factor for ectopic pregnancy. Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), often caused by sexually transmitted infections like chlamydia, can lead to scarring and damage of the fallopian tubes, increasing the risk of an ectopic pregnancy.

Risk Factors of Ectopic Pregnancy

History of PID

History of infertility

History of tubal ligation

ART particularly if the tubes are patent but damaged

Contraception failure

Intrauterine Contraceptive Device (IUCD) use

Previous ectopic pregnancy

Previous induced abortion

Tubal reconstructive surgery

Tubal endometriosis

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with lower abdominal pain and vaginal spotting at 6 weeks of gestation. An ultrasound reveals an ectopic pregnancy. Which of the following symptoms is more indicative of a ruptured ectopic pregnancy compared to an unruptured ectopic pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Abdominal distension and severe pain


Explanation:
Abdominal distension and severe pain are more indicative of a ruptured ectopic pregnancy, which can cause significant intra-abdominal bleeding and require urgent medical intervention.

Clinical presentation of Ectopic pregnancy (Triad)

  • Abdominal pain (Most consistent feature)
  • Amenorrhoea
  • Vaginal bleeding

Mild pelvic discomfort (Option A) and Asymptomatic presentations (Option D) are more common in unruptured ectopic pregnancies. Regular menstrual cycles (Option C) are not related to the symptoms of an ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe lower abdominal pain, dizziness, and shoulder tip pain. She has a history of amenorrhea for the past 7 weeks and a positive pregnancy test. On physical examination, she is pale, with a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg and a heart rate of 120 beats per minute. Which of the following diagnostic findings is most indicative of a ruptured ectopic pregnancy?

choices.text: The presence of a gestational sac in the uterine cavity on ultrasound
Free fluid in the abdomen on ultrasound
Absence of adnexal mass on pelvic exam

questions.solution:
Correct option: C) Free fluid in the abdomen on ultrasound

Explanation:
Free fluid in the abdomen on ultrasound is a key diagnostic finding indicative of a ruptured ectopic pregnancy, often representing blood from the rupture.

Investigations for ectopic pregnancy:

  • Blood examination should be done as a routine for:
    • Haemoglobin
    • ABO and Rh grouping
    • Total white cell count and differential count
    • Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)
  • Estimation of β-hCG: The suspicious find­ings are:
    • Lower concentration of β-hCG compared to normal intrauterine pregnancy
    • Plasma concentration does not double in 48 hours like in normal pregnancy
  • Sonography (TVS): The diagnostic features are:
    • Absence of intrauterine pregnancy with a positive pregnancy test.
    • Fluid (echogenic) in the pouch of Douglas.
    • Adnexal mass clearly separated from the ovary (Blob sign).
    • Rarely cardiac motion may be seen in an unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy.
  • Combination of quantitative β-hCG values and sonog­raphy: TVS provides visualization of a well-formed intrauterine gestational sac as early as 4–5 weeks from the last menstrual period. The lowest level of serum β-hCG at which a gestational sac is consistently visible using TVS (discriminatory zone) is ≥ 1,500 IU/L.So if the beta-hCG level is≥ 1,500 and no intrauterine pregnancy is seen, an ectopic pregnancy is highly suspected.
  • Laparoscopy offers benefits in cases of confusion with other pelvic lesions.
  • Dilatation and curettage: Identification of decidua without villi structure is suggestive.
  • Serum progesterone: A level greater than 25 ng/mL is suggestive of viable intrauterine pregnancy whereas a level less than 5 ng/mL suggests an ectopic or abnormal intrauterine pregnancy.
  • Laparotomy offers benefits when in doubt.

Elevated serum hCG (Option A) levels and the presence of a gestational sac (Option B) in the uterine cavity are not specific to a ruptured ectopic pregnancy.


Absence of adnexal mass on the pelvic exam (Option D): The absence of an adnexal mass on the pelvic exam does not rule out an ectopic pregnancy, especially if a rupture has occurred.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with severe lower abdominal pain and dizziness with a history of amenorrhea for the past 8 weeks. On examination, she is pale, diaphoretic, and hypotensive with a blood pressure of 80/50 mmHg and a heart rate of 120 bpm. An ultrasound confirms a ruptured ectopic pregnancy with significant intra-abdominal bleeding. The patient is in shock and requires immediate surgical intervention.

Which of the following surgical procedures is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Laparotomy with total salpingectomy

Explanation:
Laparotomy with Total Salpingectomy is the definitive management for ruptured ectopic pregnancy with shock as it allows for rapid access to the abdominal cavity, control of haemorrhage, and complete removal of the ectopic pregnancy, which is crucial in a hemodynamically unstable patient.

  • Total salpingectomy is done and not partial salpingectomy as it can potentially lead to another ectopic in the future. (Option A and C)
  • The Laparoscopic approach is suitable only for hemodynamically stable patients. (Option B)

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with acute lower abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. She has a history of amenorrhea for the past 7 weeks and reports dizziness and lightheadedness. Her vitals indicate hypotension with a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg and a heart rate of 110 bpm. Transvaginal ultrasound is unavailable at the facility. The physician decides to perform a culdocentesis to aid in the diagnosis.
Which of the following findings from the culdocentesis would suggest a ruptured ectopic pregnancy?

choices.text: Clear fluid aspirated from the pouch of Douglas
Clotting blood with a hematocrit greater than 15%
Non-clotting blood with a hematocrit greater than 15%
Purulent fluid aspirated from the pouch of Douglas

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Non-clotting blood with a hematocrit greater than 15%

Explanation:
Culdocentesis is a diagnostic procedure that involves the aspiration of fluid from the pouch of Douglas (the rectouterine pouch) through the posterior fornix of the vagina using an 18-gauge lumbar puncture needle fitted with a syringe.

  • This procedure is useful for diagnosing ruptured ectopic when diagnostic tools such as transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) or laparoscopy are not available.
  • Non-clotting blood with a hematocrit greater than 15% in the aspirate suggests a ruptured ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents to the clinic with lower abdominal pain and vaginal spotting. She has a history of amenorrhea for 7 weeks. On examination, she is hemodynamically stable. The physician suspects an unruptured ectopic pregnancy and advises USG evaluation with beta hCG assay. Which of the following findings is not typically seen for diagnosing an unruptured ectopic pregnancy?

choices.text: Absence of intrauterine pregnancy on Transabdominal sonography with beta hCG levels ≥ 1,500 IU/L.
Failure to double the value of β-hCG by 48 hours along with an empty uterus
Adnexal mass clearly separated from the ovary
Presence of ring-of-fire pattern on Colour Doppler TVS

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Absence of intrauterine pregnancy on Transabdominal sonography with beta hCG levels ≥ 1,500 IU/L


Explanation:
Transabdominal sonography (TAS) is less sensitive than transvaginal sonography (TVS) for early pregnancy detection.

  • The discriminatory zone for TAS is typically β-hCG ≥ 6,000 IU/L.
  • Therefore, the absence of an intrauterine pregnancy on TAS at a β-hCG level of ≥ 1,500 IU/L is not typically used for diagnosing ectopic pregnancy as it is not a reliable threshold for TAS.
  • TVS should be used for a more accurate diagnosis at a β-hCG level of ≥ 1,500 IU/L.

Findings for Diagnosing Unruptured Ectopic Pregnancy

Diagnostic Modality

Findings for Unruptured Ectopic Pregnancy

Transvaginal Sonography (TVS)
  • Absence of Intrauterine Pregnancy: No gestational sac within the uterine cavity when β-hCG ≥ 1500 IU/L.
  • Adnexal Mass: An adnexal mass clearly separate from the ovary (Blob sign). (Option C)
  • Ring-of-Fire Pattern: Increased blood flow around the ectopic mass on Color Doppler. (Option D)
  • Presence of pseudo gestational sac.
  • Free fluid in the Pouch of Douglas

Transabdominal Sonography (TAS)
  • Absence of Intrauterine Pregnancy: No gestational sac when β-hCG ≥ 6,000 IU/L
  • Other features: May be visible but less sensitive than TVS for smaller masses

Beta hCG Levels
  • Failure to double the value of β-hCG in 48 hours (Option B)
  • Lower concentration of β-hCG than expected for gestational age

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the clinic with lower abdominal pain and bleeding. She has a history of 8 weeks of amenorrhea. On examination, she is hemodynamically stable. Her beta hCG levels are measured at 2500 IU/L. After 48 hours, the beta hCG levels recorded are 1500 IU/L and the subsequent level recorded is 500 IU/L. TVS show no evidence of a gestational sac in the uterus and adnexa. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Non-viable Intrauterine Pregnancy


Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis is a non-viable intrauterine pregnancy (dying pregnancy).

  • In a viable intrauterine pregnancy, beta hCG levels typically double every 48 hours.
  • In this scenario, the beta hCG levels have fallen from 2500 IU/L to 2000 IU/L, and then to 1000 IU/L indicating a failing pregnancy.

Diagnosis Based on Beta hCG Levels:

Beta hCG Levels

Condition

Beta hCG levels double every 48 hours
  • Viable Intrauterine Pregnancy (Option A)

Beta hCG levels increase but not doubled (such as less than 35% in 48 hours)
  • Unruptured Ectopic Pregnancy (Option B)

Beta hCG levels decrease over time
  • Non-viable Intrauterine Pregnancy

Extremely high beta hCG level
  • Molar Pregnancy (Option D)
  • Choriocarcinoma
  • Multiple Pregnancy

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of mild lower abdominal pain and vaginal spotting. She has a history of 6 weeks of amenorrhea. On examination, she is hemodynamically stable, and a transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) reveals an adnexal mass of 3cm consistent with an unruptured ectopic pregnancy. No fetal cardiac activity is found. Her initial beta hCG level is measured at 2,000 IU/L. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Methotrexate therapy

Explanation:
Methotrexate therapy is the most appropriate management for a hemodynamically stable patient with an unruptured ectopic pregnancy and a beta hCG level less than 3,000 IU/L, provided the adnexal mass is less than 4 cm and there is no fetal cardiac activity.

Management of Unruptured Ectopic Tubal Pregnancy:

Management

Criteria/Indication

Description

Expectant Management
  • Beta hCG < 1,500 IU/L
  • No significant symptoms
  • Strong likelihood of spontaneous resolution
  • Monitoring without intervention, relying on the natural resolution of the ectopic pregnancy

Medical Management
  • Beta hCG < 3,000 IU/L
  • Adnexal mass < 4 cm
  • No fetal cardiac activity
  • Hemodynamically stable
  • Methotrexate (single dose/ multi-dose regimen) (best)
  • KCl (directly in sac)
  • Mifepristone
  • Prostaglandins

Surgical Management
  • Beta hCG > 5,000 IU/L
  • Size of ectopic > 4 cm
  • Presence of cardiac activity
  • Linear Salpingostomy (best)
  • Resection Anastomosis

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding methotrexate as treatment for unruptured ectopic pregnancy ?

choices.text: Single dose of 100 mg/m² given intramuscularly
Decline in hCG of 15% or more between Day 1 and 3 indicates successful treatment
A single dose of 50 mg methotrexate is given intravenously.
A second dose of methotrexate given on Day 7 if decline in hCG is less than 15%

questions.solution:
Correct option: D) A second dose of methotrexate given on Day 7 if decline in hCG is less than 15%

 

Explanation:

Methotrexate Protocol for the management of unruptured tubal pregnancy:

  • Involves a single dose of 50 mg/m² given intramuscularly(Option A) (Option C)
  • After administration, serum β-hCG levels are monitored on Day 4 and Day 7
    • A decline in hCG of 15% or more between Day 4 and Day 7 (Option B) indicates successful treatment,
    • The patient is followed up weekly with serum hCG monitoring until the level falls below 10 mIU/mL.
    • If the decline in hCG is less than 15% between Day 4 and Day 7, a second dose of methotrexate (50 mg/m²) may be given on Day 7.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman’s transvaginal ultrasound reveals a 5 cm ectopic pregnancy located in the ampulla of the right fallopian tube. The initial serum beta hCG level was 3500 IU/L and has remained stable despite receiving three doses of methotrexate. What is the most appropriate management option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct option: D) Laparoscopic salpingectomy


Explanation:
This patient has an unruptured ectopic pregnancy in the right fallopian tube that has failed to respond to medical management with methotrexate.

  • Laparoscopic salpingectomy involves the removal of the affected fallopian tube. It is indicated when medical therapy fails or is contraindicated, such as in cases of larger ectopic pregnancies (> 4 cm) or persistent beta hCG levels.

 

Expectant management (Option A) involves observation of the patient, hoping for spontaneous resolution. This is a viable option in cases where the beta hCG level is low or falling.

Hysterectomy (Option B) is not considered a management option for ectopic pregnancy.

Laparoscopic linear salpingostomy (Option C) is done only in H/O infertility or if the unaffected tube is also looking unhealthy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication of expectant management of unruptured tubal pregnancy?

choices.text: The initial beta hCG level is less than 2500 IU/L
Gestation sac size less than 4 cm
No evidence of bleeding on USG

questions.solution:
Correct option: A) Initial beta hCG level is less than 2500 IU/L


Explanation:
Indications for expectant management of ectopic pregnancy (only monitoring hCG levels without any interventions):

  • Initial serum hCG level is less than 1,500 IU/L and subsequent levels are decreasing.
  • Gestational sac size is less than 4 cm.(Option C)
  • Absence of fetal heartbeat detected (Option B) on transvaginal ultrasound (TVS).
  • No evidence of bleeding (Option D) or rupture on transvaginal ultrasound (TVS)

questions.text: Which of the following statements about interstitial ectopic is false?

choices.text: Interstitial line sign on ultrasound is specific for interstitial ectopic.
Interstitial ectopic produces a myometrial bulge lateral to the round ligament.
Interstitial ectopic is typically associated with a thicker myometrial mantle surrounding the sac.
Interstitial ectopics rupture later as compared to other tubal ectopics.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Interstitial ectopic is typically associated with a thicker myometrial mantle surrounding the sac.

Explanation:

  • Interstitial ectopic implants within the tubal segment that lies within the uterine cornu (interstitial portion of tube). They usually rupture following 8 - 16 weeks of amenorrhea, which is later than other ectopics. the myometrium covering the interstitial portion of fallopian tube segment permits greater distention before rupture. (Option D)
  • Because of the proximity of these ectopics to the uterine & ovarian arteries, hemorrhage can be severe.
  • On USG they can appear similar to an eccentrically implanted intrauterine pregnancy (angular pregnancy), but in interstitial ectopic the uterus will be empty & an echogenic line is seen extending from the gestational sac to the endometrial cavity (the line represents the interstitial portion of fallopian tube), known as the "interstitial line sign" is highly sensitive & specific for the diagnosis. (Option A)
  • Also the myometrial mantle surrounding the gestational sac is thin (< 5 mm) (Option C is the false statement). In an angular pregnancy the myometrium surrounding the gestational sac is not thinned out as the pregnancy is intrauterine.
  • Laparoscopically, a myometrial protuberance is seen to lie lateral to the round ligament in case of interstitial ectopic. (Option B). In angular pregnancy it is medial to round ligament.
  • Surgical management involves cornual resection (removing the gestational sac & surrounding myometrium) via laparoscopy or laparotomy, depending on patient hemodynamic stability & surgeon expertize. With early diagnosis, medical management may be considered.

questions.text: Which condition is Spiegelberg's criteria used to diagnose?
questions.solution:
Correct option: A) Ovarian pregnancy

Explanation:
Spiegelberg's criteria for the diagnosis of ovarian pregnancy:

  • The fallopian tube on the affected side must be intact.
  • The gestational sac must be located within the ovary.
  • The gestational sac is connected to the uterus via the ovarian ligament.
  • Ovarian tissue must be identified on histological examination of the sac wall.

 

Cesarean scar pregnancy(Option B) is defined as implantation into the myometrial defect in the site of the previous uterine scar

Abdominal Pregnancy(Option C) Studdiford’s criteria is used for the diagnosis of Abdominal Pregnancy

Cervical Pregnancy(Option D) Rubin’s criteria is used for the diagnosis of cervical pregnancy
